title: 114_s1959
content: The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2015" includes a lifetime ban on members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2015" imposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2015" imposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying. Section 207(e)(2) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to remove references to elected officers of the Senate and former elected officers. The "Close the Revolving Door Act of 2015" imposes a lifetime ban on former members of Congress from lobbying. Section 207(e) of title 18, United States Code, is amended to extend the ban from 1 year to 6 years for congressional staff. Additionally, the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to establish a joint lobbyist disclosure Internet database called lobbyists.gov for easy public access to lobbying information. SEC. 5. LOBBYIST REVOLVING DOOR TO CONGRESS. In this section, definitions for "foreign principal," "lobbyist," and "registered lobbyist" are provided. It prohibits registered lobbyists or agents of foreign principals from being hired by a Member or committee of Congress they have lobbied within 6 years. Waivers can be granted in the Senate or the House. (c) Waiver may be granted by the Select Committee on Ethics of the Senate or the Committee on Standards of Official Conduct of the House of Representatives based on a compelling national need. For determining substantial lobbying contact, consideration is given to lobbying activities related to pending legislative business, solicitation of earmarks or Federal funding, coordination of meetings, presentations to congressional employees, and fundraising participation. Participation in fundraising does not constitute substantial lobbying contacts, except for personal contributions. Simple social contacts with members of Congress or staff do not count as substantial lobbying contacts. SEC. 6A. REPORTING BY SUBSTANTIAL LOBBYING ENTITIES. Substantial lobbying entities must annually report to the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate a list of individuals who are former Senators, former Members of the House of Representatives, or other covered legislative branch officials meeting specific criteria. The filing required under this section shall contain job descriptions and work experience of individuals in specified positions. The Joint Web site lobbyists.gov will include a database of 'Substantial Lobbying Entities'. Law enforcement oversight will be provided by the Clerk of the House of Representatives and the Secretary of the Senate. The filing under this section must be provided to the US Attorney for the District of Columbia to check for underreporting by substantial lobbying entities, defined as entities with more than 3 registered lobbyists. SEC. 7 of the Lobbying Disclosure Act of 1995 is amended to increase penalties from $200,000 to $500,000.
